jodd.json

Class JoddJson

extends java.lang.Object
    Jodd JSON module.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_CLASS_METADATA_NAME

        public static final java.lang.String DEFAULT_CLASS_METADATA_NAME
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • jsonAnnotation

        public static java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.annotation.Annotation> jsonAnnotation
        Annotation used for marking the properties.

      • defaultSerializers

        public static TypeJsonSerializerMap defaultSerializers
        Default JSON type serializers.

      • classMetadataName

        public static java.lang.String classMetadataName
        Specifies if 'class' metadata is used. When set, class metadata is used by JsonSerializer and all objects will have additional field with the class type in the resulting JSON. JsonParser will also consider this flag to build correct object type. If null, class information is not used.

      • deepSerialization

        public static boolean deepSerialization
        Defines default behavior of a JsonSerializer. If set to true, objects will be serialized deep, so all collections and arrays will get serialized.

      • useAltPathsByParser

        public static boolean useAltPathsByParser
        Defines if parser will use extended paths information and path matching.

      • excludedTypes

        public static java.lang.Class[] excludedTypes
        List of excluded types for serialization.

      • excludedTypeNames

        public static java.lang.String[] excludedTypeNames
        List of excluded types names for serialization. Type name can contain wildcards (* and ?).

      • serializationSubclassAware

        public static boolean serializationSubclassAware
        When true, then search for first annotated class or interface and use it's data.

      • annotationManager

        public static JsonAnnotationManager annotationManager
        Default JSON annotation manager.

      • strictStringEncoding

        public static boolean strictStringEncoding
        JSON specification specifies that certain characters should be escaped (see: http://json.org/). However, in the real world, not all needs to be escaped: especially the 'solidus' character (/). If this one is escaped, many things can go wrong, from URLs to Base64 encodings. This flag controls the behavior of strict encoding. By default, the strict encoding is set to false.
